awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  High-resolution profiling of histone modifications responsible for heterochromatin repair
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

DNA is continually subject to damage and life depends on repairing it. The consequences of failure are especially high in heterochromatin, the which mostly consists of highly compact DNA-protein structures and repeated DNA sequences. While repair failures in normal chromatin can lead to deleterious mutations, incorrect repair within repetitive heterochromatic regions can trigger rearrangements that cause cell death or genome instability. This project will use new experimental approaches and methods in the fruit fly to understand heterochromatic repair pathways at the chromatin level. This work will yield fundamental advances in our understanding of the role of chromatin modifications on genome integrity, and the project itself creates excellent educational opportunities for junior researchers to participate in training, teaching, mentoring and outreach activities, launching their careers in science while inspiring others. Specific attention for inclusion of undergraduate and high school students from underrepresented groups will expose more women and low-income students to STEM fields. These research and educational activities will increase their career opportunities while diversifying the pipeline of future scientists and broadening perspectives to solve future societal challenges. This project will also involve organizing a "SoCal Genome Stability" symposium that will enhance the dissemination of knowledge, open new networking, research and career opportunities for junior and senior scientists at colleges and universities across Southern California. 

Nearly 30% of the human genome comprises pericentromeric heterochromatin, where defective repair of double-strand breaks (DSB) can lead to widespread genome rearrangements. Previous studies revealed specialized mechanisms required for 'safe' homologous recombination (HR) repair of these sequences, including a poorly understood role for histone marks. This study will shed light on the role of chromatin composition and regulation in heterochromatin repair in Drosophila. It will combine the unique strengths of the Drosophila model system, with innovative tools for site-specific DSB induction and next-generation sequencing. This combination of approaches will enable the first high-resolution profiling of chromatin dynamics responsible for heterochromatic repair, significantly advancing the understanding of genome stability mechanisms in multi-cellular eukaryotes.

Research outcomes: 

This research significantly advanced our understanding of the basic mechanisms that maintain genome integrity. Our cells are constantly exposed to DNA damage, caused by environmental factors like radiation and chemicals or by normal cellular activities such as DNA replication. Repairing this damage is essential for preserving intact genetic information, enabling cell survival, and supporting normal cellular functions. DNA double-stranded breaks are the most severe type of DNA damage because they interrupt genetic information. Repairing these breaks is particularly challenging in heterochromatin, a large genomic component composed mostly of repeated DNA sequences. These sequences are more prone to damage and errors during repair, which can cause chromosomal rearrangements, genome instability, cancer, and other genetic disorders and developmental defects. Heterochromatin is characterized by a unique state of the chromatin, the basic organizational unit of the DNA. Chromatin consists of DNA wrapped around histone proteins, which are modified to create distinct "chromatin states" that regulate whether DNA is transcriptionally active or inactive. Heterochromatin is typically transcriptionally inactive, and this study aimed to understand how this state influences DNA repair or changes during the DNA damage response. A key discovery from this research is that the silenced state of heterochromatin facilitates the initiation of DNA repair, contrary to the common belief that its “closed” state hinders repair. This finding establishes a new paradigm in which silent chromatin positively contributes to DNA repair rather than opposing to it. The study also uncovered global changes in the silenced heterochromatin state, which are required for repair progression. These findings offer a new framework for understanding how human cells maintain a stable genome despite being composed mostly of repetitive DNA sequences. Dysregulation of these pathways is responsible to genome instability disorders, including cancer and other aging-related human diseases. DNA repair defects are also responsible for sterility, developmental defects, and neurological and neuromuscular disorders. This research lays the groundwork for understanding the molecular causes of these conditions and, over time, developing better approaches for early detection and treatment.

Educational outcomes: 

This award supported the training of 35 young investigators at various career stages, including five postdocs, five graduate students, nineteen undergraduate students, several rotation students, and one high school student. Trainees enhanced their research, teaching, and mentoring skills, with most earning fellowships and awards for their contributions to science. They have advanced to prestigious careers in research or medicine at leading universities and research centers, including at Harvard, Stanford and Yale. Senior trainees have pursued careers in academia and industry, extending the impact of their training across disciplines. This work has also helped promote the representation of women in STEM by training and mentoring 16 talented women scientists, enhancing their career potential. The research findings were shared through more than 60 conference presentations, 17 scientific publications, and 7 public outreach articles, broadening the impact of this research across fields. Results from these studies have also been shared with undergraduate students at the University of Southern California in four main courses, positively impacting the diffusion of knowledge and students’ training in modern biology. Further, the award supported the annual SoCal Genome Stability Symposium, providing junior scientists from Southern California’s universities and research centers a platform to share their work in a collaborative and supportive environment. This symposium also fosters training, mentoring, and networking opportunities, while also attracting participants from smaller undergraduate institutions and liberal arts colleges. This expanded access to research resources has helped engage more students in science and improve their career prospects. In summary, this award achieved exceptional training and mentoring outcomes, significantly advanced our knowledge of DNA repair mechanisms, and made a broad impact on science and society.
